div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,143] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels.
div.p: Catarnot Hotel, Assouan.

Thos most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the additoon of 65 rooms and accomodates 360 gruests. Grand dining hall, lift, tennis courts and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billiard room and bar., Electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel Assouan. - Under the same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 50 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrance overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

div.head: Grand Hotel Khartoum

div.head: THE S.P.C.A. in EGYTPT
div.p: We should like to call the attention both of our regular readers and of the visitors staying in Egypt, whose numbers are greater now than they have ever been, to the tenth annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Mr. Horaoe Rumbold, the honorary secretary and treasurer of the society, in his most interesting report, which is accompanied by very full statements of aooounts and of the financial position of the branches established at Zagazig, Mansourah, Tantah, Assiout, Luxor, and Assouan, notes that both the balance and the receipts from subscriptions and donations have diminished during the past year. The falling off in subscriptions he ascribes to the foot that many former subscribers have left Egypt, while their places have remained unfilled. The decrease in the donations indicates either indifference to the aims of the society, or a complete misunderstanding of its financial position. Ignorance cannot well be pleaded : there is not a single large hotel at Cairo, or Helouan where the notices of the 8-P.C.A. do not occupy prominent positions, and it is impossible to imagine for a moment that the average tourist has suddenly become hardened to the possibility of animal suffering. There remains the other alternative: that one visitors mis understand the financial situation of the society, and this we believe to be the cause of the decreased support which Mr. { Rumbled notes. In this the last paragraph of the report deserves quotation in ; fulfill "The society has now completed 10 years' work, during which it may fairly claim to have | brought about a complete change in the Condition of animals in and around Cairo. Visitors and residents, who have known Cairo before S.P.C.A. existed, are unanimous in bearing wi ness to the revolution brought about through the agency. The sum recovered in the course the year from owners of animals treats in the infirmary must inevitably constitute the largest proportion of the income of the society. Experience has shown, however, this the receipts under this head can never equate the expenditure, and that the society will • ways be dependent, to & certain extent, c outside contributions. Residents in Egypt fully do their duty in supporting the society The same cannot be said of the thousands will visit Egypt every winter. The contribution of visitors during 1904 scarcely reached L.E.2 out of a total income of over L.K.3,500. J no year have they exceed L.K.100. £ platonic sympathy with the and objects of the society are readily forth coming, but do not assume a concrete or practical shape" The italics are ours, for to passage deserves to be emphasised : it is eat to assume an interested sympathetic air but unfortunately this simulated interest has a wi of departing with those who have aroused i Quite number of otherwise excellent people respond to an appeal to their sympathy adult generosity with the regularity of one of tho pleasing machines, once so popular in British seaside resorts, into while penny was insert! and a puppet willingly danced or played put the simulacrum of a musical instrument, ai with about the same practical result.

We confess to a fear that exhortations ai appeals will prove vain against such meter cal temperaments, but there must be urban of whiter visitors whose intellects are as precept cal as their instincts are generous, and who Da to support the S.P.C.A. as it( deserves owing! a misapprehension of its financial position. realise as well as they do that the society to deal with Cairo thoroughly and effectively, but they do not realise that, unless • the society to mark time, perhaps for years, then help needed to enable it to extend its operation in the provinces. A society that confirm its work for ever to the Capital you deserve to be compared to a police thi enforced peace and order in London, Brig ton, Birmingham, and Manchester and, oo tentedly supine, permitted outlaws to reassei bio in Sherwood Forest and highwayman to haunt the Portsmouth road. It is ti wish of the committee and members of to S.P.C.A. to give to their operations a wid scope, and sooner or later to establish enter at all the principal towns in Egypt, from who the treatment of animals, not only in the towns, but in the surrounding villages, can I watched, and infraction* of the laws relating cruelty to animals noted and brought before the responsible authorities. Anyone who 1 the fellaheen of Egypt understands that all their good points, they are curiously less of animal suffering, and indict a amount of unnecessary pain on the beasts of they possess and, at times, on the wild tares that Call into their hands. We do wish to give any colour to the that the Moslem is cruel to beasts hi Moslem, for the enlightened Mob holds strong views as to his duty town animals, and will bite passages from Koran in favor of humanity. But ran in Christian and in ^lost cities is usually accompanied by a cruelty towards animal suffering, the consequence of which differ in no way from those active cruelty, and the fellah is admitted ignorant and callous. We therefore vent to appeal to our visitors to remember the there are other places in Egypt besides Cair Luxor, and Assouan, and that while to S.P.C.A. has done great things in a limits area and with limited resources, it needs help to enable it to continue and to extend its work. No amount of good wishes balances a donation, however small.

div.head:
BATTLE STILL RAGING.
RUSSIANS IN FULL RETREAT.
Mukdin's Fall Imminent
BLOODiEST BATTLE OF WAR.
APPALING LOSSES.

div.p: Marshal Oyama reporta that a. division of the enemy with 70 guns was repulsed at Taahicliinu, ei^lit mi his to the north-west ui Mukden. * Inc battle is proceeding favorably lor us some 10 miles to the south-east, and the same distance -to the south oi Fu&hau despite the stubborn resistance of the enemy/' The report doea uot. indicate substantial progress anywhere. (Hauler.)

Reuter s Agency learns trorn Mukden that on the bth iust., the sixth day of the battle, the ligating on the west llank raged uuceas* gly irom (lawn till dusk. The Japanese were < huuiy established at Machiapu, and they Iso pushed their line iurther north, 'xussian losses already exceed those at . and it is estimated that the Jupa- •les are greater.
S mat., the Japanese continued , jovement. One division extend- ec ection of Tiding. '1 he firing ol its

urti shifted north almost to the Sm-Miu- Ting oad, lioin whence a number of Japanese w blinded were biougbt in. Fighting was .also ueard lur away to the north. The attack on tue front was meanwhile* maintained, 'ihu Japanese are re-advanciug on the extreme east, i he Russians are still holding the centre, but nu the south-west are retiring on their second positions.(Hauler, j
The Russians evacuated the line east of the Ska Ho during the night. {Havas.,
General Kuropatkin telegraphs on the 7th inst. that the enemy's attacks have been repulsed in the centre and left dank. (Havas.j
The Japaueso captured Machuntan in the morning. (Havas, j
The battlo continues to rage and is exhausting both sides. The dual issue is still hauging in the balance. (Hauler./

Reuter's correspondent with General Kuroki cabling on Wednesday states that the Russians, profiting by the darkness, evacuated ail the positions along the Sba-Ho. They are now in full retreat. They fired huge quantities ol supplies. The Japanese are pressing them haid and the fall of Mukden is imminent.

Reuter's corre.-poudent with General Oku says that, owing to the tlatuess of the Cuuutry, the battle on the west is entirely conducted by telephone. The Russians latterly have been demoralised by the irresistible rushes of the Japanese. It is believed that some Russian regiments are on the vergo of mutiny.
The Jap&i.ese are now bridging the Hun-Ho.
( Hauler.
A Russian telegram from Mukden says that yesterday at 10.0 iu the morning the heavy caunDnading on the northwest was shaking the houses of the town.
Au engagement was proceeding near the Imperial tombs. (Heutar.j
General Kuropatkin has evidently been badly .eaten in the most bloody battle of the war.'
(Otficial). The Russiaus began retreating yesterday morning. t All the Japanese armies iro vigorously pursuing them. (Heutar.)

The "times" learns from St. Petersburg that ieneral Kuropatkin reported yesterday tliat ke Japanese had massed an enormous force o the north-west of Mukden,thus necessitating n immediate retreat The Russian losses uring the first ten days of the battle are offi- ially given as being nearly 33,000, including 30 officers. (Reuter.)

The "Times" says that the French finan- rs intimated to Russia tliat the new loan i«t not exceed £20,000,000 instead of 2,000,000, and, furthermore, that this will the last loan to be raised in Paris for some rs. (Reuter.)
Phe British colliers "Venus" and "Aphrodite," bound for Vladivostok, have been seised oy the Japanese t (Reuter.)
'lhe movement of revolt in the country districts of Russia is gaining strength. Bauds of armed peasants are marching through the, villages damaging property. (Reuter.)
The men of the Baltic Naval dockyard hore have struck work, owing to the arrest of their elected representatives. (Reuter.)

div.p: The Ministry of Public Works is atpreseut engaged in the investigation and study of the most up-to-date opera bouses in Europe aud America, and ha« specially studied the problem ot how to deal with the risk of fire. div.head: THE EGYPTIN PILGRIMAGE
div.p: . RETURN OF SACRED CARPET.

The first batch of Egyptian pilgrims returning from Mecca left Jeddah yesterday by the Khedivial Mail steamer "Assouan," and the Sacred Carpet with the escort, suite, andpilgrims accompanying, left Jeddah on Tuesday by the same company's S.S. 'Rahmanieh," "Payoum," and "Negbileh" for Yambo, en route for Medina.

div.head: RODAH ISLAND.
div.p: The Cairo newspapers have been publishing a number of incorrect statements as to the proposals for the purchase ol 52 feddans on Rodah Islaud by Messrs. Zervudachi & Co. The land in question does not belong to the Wakfs Administration but to the heirs of Aly Pasha Cherif, and the Wakfs Administration has only managed the property provisionally until the heirs come to some agreement. One of the heira has made an "opposition legale" to the sale.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES, LTD.
div.p: We arc informed that the ordinary shares of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, are being dealt in on the London Stock Exchange at 5a. premium.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: LONDON OPINION.
A London financial correspondent writes :—

The expected movement in Egyptian miuing shares is at hand, or at any rate it seems so. Norlh Niles will probably wait ontil Nile Valleys give a lead, but those in the market who regard them with even greater favor than the shares of the older company (from a purely market standpoint) are not entirely without reasons. The issued capital is very small, only about £39,000, and an appreciation in price would probably be more rapid in the case ot the subsidiary than in that of the parent. By band crushing alone £3,000 worth of gold bsB been recovered, and 5,000 feet of development work has been done, Nubias are quiet, and so are the rest of the list, but there are various considerations which point to an impending revival of interest in this section.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
div.p: The report for 1904 states that the Urn Rus Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited) with a capital of £150,000, of which £50,000 is working capital, was ' issued to the public on the 6th of February last year, and the purchase consideration of £5,000 cash aud 33,333 fully-paid shares has been paid over to the company. It is expected that regular crush- ings on the Um Rus Mine will commence in the course of a few weeks. Five thousand of the remaining 40,000 unisoued working capital shares were applied for and allotted at the close of the financial year. The company has now ample funds in hand, as the subsidiary companies in which they are largely interested are carrying on the development work, and no expenditure on this account is being incurred by the company. Just after the close of the year the Sudan Minos (Limited) was formed to acquire the Sudan Concession, with a capital of £60,000, of which £20,000 is working capital, the company receiving 12,833 shares, fully paid, for the concession.

div.head: PILOTAGE AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Finance Miuistry has altered danse 14 of the Alexandria Pilotage Rules, of the 31st December, 1896. The clause now reads as follows :—

"Si les pilotes se trouvent dans l'imposri- bilitl d'aborder les navires k cause de la grosse mer, ie signal V du Code International sera hiss<$ kbord du remorqueur ou de rembarca- tion des pilotes pour indiqner que l'abordage n'est pas possible. En pared cas, le navire devra franohir la passe sous la direction de ses propres officiers ou res ter en dehors de la passe jusqu'h ce que le temps devienne suffi- samment cal me pour permettro au pilote de monter kbord.
"Ce drapeau sera hissl kbord do bateau* pilote indlpendamment de tout autre signal de cette nature fait à Kom-EFNadoure."

div.head: HGHEZIREEH CASINO BALL.
div.p: A BRILLIANT SPECTACLE.

The fancy-drees ball at the Ghezireh Casino on Tuesday night was a remarkably brilliant and successful entertainment. Residents and visitors came in crowds, some powdered, many in fancy dress, and it was one of those nights when the phrase "nearly everybody seems to be here" was true for once in a way. A list of those who were present would be too long for our space—and perhaps for our readers—besides being impossible to give, and we oonfine ourselves to a description of the costumes that impressed us most, though we cannot pretend to describe the dresses worn by so many fair members of tbe more charming sex, and mtast apologise to all those whom we may leave uomentioned for the lack of taste that drove us to neglect, or the forgetfulness that prevent- ed us from noting, what they wore.

The ball room of the Ghezireh Palace Casino always looks well when lit up and decorated, and never looked better than on Tuesday night, wheu the costumesof the dancers,mostly in excellent taste, and worn with grace, made a wonderful 'V»up d'ceil." It would be i possible to piok opt tbe best—comparisons of costumes are the most odious of all,—but we may say that Mr. Geoffrey Milward, in black and orange brown, was one of the finest Morgans or Captains Kidds that we have ever seen. Mrs. Milward, powdered aud in rich brocade, deserves special praise for not waving her hair; result—a costume thoroughly in keeping with the XVillth century and historically accurate. Many others wore their hair in the manner of the XXth century, and the picture, charming in parts, just failed to oonvince as a whole.

Another pirate, and a gigantic and redoubtable figure in three-cornered hat and waving plumes, was Bimbashi Kelly, E.A. Bimbasbi Cummins looked well as a Rapin from Montmartre, and we must not forget Capt. Byrne as a Mousquetaire of the Guard of the Bourbons, and Capt. Jeimings (R. I. Fus.), who impersonated with singular accuracy an Egyptian warrior of the monuments. Miss Rees looked charming as a paysanne. Miss Joseph and Miss Walford were Veroniques : each had treated the part in a different spirit and each succeeded iu giving a charming picture of Messager's heroine. Miss Pigeon as Queen Winter, adomed with holly and icicles, and Miss Gladys Royle, as a white and stately Dresden shepherdess, were amazingly good., and we must not forget Mr. Young, arrayed as a buck of George IV.'s days. There were groups, too. and the best of these came from the officers of the 2ud Royal Inniskiliing Fusiliers, Mrs. Steward, as "Alice in Wonderland," leading into the ball room all the heroes of the story, the Mad Hatter, Tweedledum and Tweed led ee, the Red aud White Queens, the White Knight, long spoon for the nasal of his helmet, course the Walrus and the Carpenter, its and Pierrettes swarmed, as did the the suits, and Queens of Hearts and Kings ofl^iamouds. There were Dervishes, too, of ferocious aspect, amoug whom Major Delavoye and Capt Bigge doomed large on the limited horizon ol the ball-room. Mr. Forestier- Walker had the happy idea of appearing as a black "La Tosca." Capt Whiffen was a very desperate-looking desperado, and Capt Tncker a huge aud picturesque stock rider. Mr. Soott- Moncrieff was a dark and diabolical Arab ; will be pardon ns for saying that he evoked memories of coaling at Port Said ? Mr. Peyton aud Mr. Clogstouu were sailor-boys, while Mr. Paxton and Mr. Tod appeared as costers in all the glory of pearlies and wonderfully cat continuations. Dr. Phillips, as a barrister, Mr. Welldon, as a convict, and Mr. Hankey, as a cavalier, all deserve mention. There were Japanese of both sexes, among whom Mrs. Garrett, Mrs. Drummond-Hay, and Miss Hume were charming Geishas. Mrs. Warnock as a Marquise and Mrs. Elliot Smith as Evangeline looked extremely well, and Mrs. Symmors was a most successful Portia. Many ladies bad merely powdered, and powder suited them.- Mrs. Wild and Mrs. Donegan looked very well so, while pictoies served as models to Miss Caution, who made a charming Romney, and to Mrs. Ray, who in powder, ringlets, skirts and picture hat, followed Gainsborough. Mr. Moroorn was an effective Sheikh. Messrs. Hicks and ltobiuson were impressive students of A1 Azhar, while Maj. Donegan and Mr. S. de Bilinaki appeared in hunting pink. There were some splendid Bedouins, Mr. Niabet and Mr. Bennett perhaps most striking of them all, and Miss de Codt was a picturesque aud accurate Dolly Varden. Mr. Blencowe came as a Toreador, as did Capt Carey, who was aocompauied by Miss Carey, who was remarkably good as Cannon, and we must not forget Mohamed Bey—we do not know which of the many Mohamed Beys he is, but hear that he is Prince Halim's wakeel— who came arrayed as a Pathan notable.

The Hon. Arthur Davey looked extremely well as a Pierrot The Hon. Mrs. Davey was very much admired as "Black and White." Another very artistic costume was that of Miss Leverich, in black and silver, as "Night" Then there was a Sunflower Girl and many others, the vague memory of whom makes us curse our forgetfulness of the details of their dress.

The dancing was animated. That goes without saying on such occasions. At 1 a.m. a great multitude swarmed to supper and overflowed to side rooms where flash-light photos were taken. After supper came more dancing till 5.15 a.m., when the ball at last ended. The arrangements were as perfect as they always are at Ghezireh. May the Savoy dance on the 14th rival this—it will be very hard to surpass it.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: it may be safely stated that the source* of information at the disposal of the magnate* of the London Stock Exchange are more far-rr ch- ing and reliable than any other. Even the I eat opinion of the chances of succees of the armies in the field, with all the gathered available news from public and private sources, can be, and no doubt is, secured by those to whom the upshot of events means loss or gain of many millions. When, therefore, a movement of general confidence takes place, and Consols and other securities (whioh,so to speak,"beattime") and Japanese Stocks show special strength, it is easy to gauge "the fact" that the best informed have made up their minds as to the general course of events. The latest information from Manchuria seems to have fully confirmed these views, and amply justified the discounting of the future that has taken place. There is ofily oue weak spot. Will the French* holders of Kmmi*n stock lose their heads "en masse" in case of the farther casualties impeding ? T' at the fall of Port Arthur, the destructio t oi .he Russian fleet, and the state of practical t t u tion into which Russia has been plunge a by the insensate action oi the Tsar, have been borne by the French investor frith extraordi nary ''sang froid," so much so that the power of obtaining new loans in that country seems still unexhausted,give reason to hope that they will bear future troubles without panic. Certainly the conditions of sale, and the advioe from head-centres, will act in that direction. The French are, however, an impulsive people, aud liable to act foolishly when once "on the run." Should the scare take place, what would be the effect t This has been well thought-out and discussed in high financial circles this week, with the conclusion that, with prices of best securities at their present level, there is not much to fear. The weight ot a heavy drop would fall on Paris, and „at the moment, being in au exceptionally strong monetary position, should be able to bear it. French holders of South African shares would, no doubt, be obliged to realise to some extent, heuce the halting condition of that market,but otherwise the effect on our Stock Exchange would' be mostly sympathetic, and the result of near peace, coming as an offset to Russian disasters, would have a strengthening tendency. The very lall in Russians, if it take place, will make an unanswerable argument for peeoe, for, as Napoleon said, to oommand success in war three things are essential1st, money; 2nd, money; 3rd, money.

Gilt-edged securities still continue to be the leading feature of the stock-markets, and at the time of writing they stand generally at the highest .level touched lor a long time past Money is cheap, and, what is more important, there is strong evidence that, in this section at any rate, there is a revival of public confidence. Thure has been a steady demand for better-class stocks, which has been well sustained dining the past lew weeks. The supply of investment stocks is comparatively limited, and a continuance of buying in this quarter, such as seems more than probable, mast ultimately so raise prices that in a lew months' time, perhaps ieas,they will teach a level which will yield a very much smaller return, and moreover, leave much less scope for speculation than is the case at present. Then we shall see the further result, viz. the poblio will turn to those markets which offer them most scope, and there will be a consequent return ol activity in speculative stocks. Egyptian properties have fluctuated- considerably this week. Natiou&l Bauks are the most active feature, having fallen beluw 26$ early in the week, but steadied again to 27 later. It is only to be expected that the rapid rise in prioe should produce a fairly large amount of profit making, for, good-as this property undoubtedly is, the upward movement has been very rapid, and the return at pieseut is certainly not proportionate, still less high enough to tempt holders to look them up at these prioes. Agricultural Banks are steady at lli- Daira Sanieh shares keep their prioe well at 25}r and are talked higher. Egyptiau Salt and Soda at 2| seem high, but the shares are well held, and we should not recommend selling "on speo." We believe the purchase of the Huileries is practically settled. Amongst forthcoming issues is the Egyptian Trust and Investment Co. with a capital ot £200,000. It is not yet on the market, bat as the capital is not large, and some good financial names are mentioned in connection with it, it might easily be made a success in the present prosperous state of Egyptian finanoes. There is a rather better U ne in the mining section generally at the moment Egyptian mining oompanies already show a distinot advanoe on last week's prioes, though as yet business is very limited in the mining market generally. Egypt and Sudan stand at 2 which includes a dividend of 25 per cent and rights to the value of another 75 % in shares of the Sudan Goldfield, Ltd., and the prioe seems low.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. H. Prinoe Adalbert, third soa of the Emperor William, who is a lieutenant on board the German cruiser "Hertha," is staying at Shephsard's Hotel, having come on to Cairo from Fort Said.

The Bail and Countess of IimMissIwsOigh entertained a party at dinner at tfis Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening,tbs guests incl ud mg the Horn J. W. Riddle, the Mis«e Harley, and Lord George Chobnoodeley.
Sir Ernest Cassel and party are axpeoted back in Cairo shortly.
Mr. George Faber, M.P., and Mrs. Faber, who are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, are
leaving for Europe by the S.S. "Canopic".
General and Mrs. Lance have returned to the Tewfik Palace Hotel from up-Kver.

A wound received in Egypt in 1882, two days before the battle of Kassassin, has just been the cause of the death of Mr. Rowland Lewis, which occurred ten days ago io consequence of inflammation from the wound. Deceased joined the 2nd Life Guards, volun teered for Egypt, and was wounded at Tel-el Kebir. For the last ten years he had been one oi the Assessors of Income Tax in the City ol London._
The German Emperor has conferred th< decoration known as "The Cross of the Orowi of Pruseia" on Mr. A. H. Skynder, architect of Cairo. _

"General" Booth has left London for hii visit to Jerusalem, Australia, and New Zealand travelling viA Dover and Calais to Marseille for Port Said. At the latter place he wil branch off for Jaffa and Jerusalem, returning to Port Said for Colombo, where he is t< arrive on March 28. Thenoe he will prooeed to Australia. «
Dr. Paul Hildebrandt has Jbeen authorisec to follow his profession in Egypt

div.head: NOVELLI AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The stirring adventures that happened tc the great Italian actor Signor NoveUi, as he was on the point of arriving at Alexandria, enhanced the interest of his appearance at the Zizinia Theatre last night, and all Alexandria flocked to hear and see him in AUeiuja. The drama was suited to the occasion as all the characters were garbed in every-day dress, so the complete loss of the troupe's wardrobe in the "Cairo" was not remarked. NoveUi took the rOle of Alessandro F&ra and was greeted with tremendous applause on making his first appearance. Novelli's monologue at the dose oi the performance was received with enthusiasm.

div.head: AMATEUR THEATRICALS.
div.p: Enjoyable musical or dramatio entertainments at St Catherine's College, Alexandria, are by no means of rare oocurrenoe, and these are looked forward to with pleasurable expectancy, by professors, pupils, parents, and friends alike, for some weeks prior to the actual date of performance. We have been privileged to witness many of these entertainments, and to receive, frequently, the weff-known generous hospitality at the hands of the good Brothers. Tuesday's "slanos rtar&tive et musicals," which was under the distinguished patronage and presence of M. Pierre Girard, Consul of France, proved no exception to the role, and the attractive nature of the programme brought a large crowd of patroffs long before the hour announced for the opening of the doors. The first part of the programme consisted of a musical extravaganza entitled The Happy Man, adapted by Mr. J. Pearoe-Hill, who also introduced several original songs, painted the very effective settings of scenery, and trained the little company of some fifteen youngsters who took part in the prodoo- tion. The performance was, in every way, an unqualified suooesa ; indeed, some of the young artistes showed suoh histrionic ability as might weU be envied by much older aspirants. As the Rajah, Mr. Nelson Schranz was impressive and acted with ease and dignity. This remark also applies to Mr. G. Garcia, who ably supported the rile of Prinoe Foxi, the grand Vizier. Mr. H. Klat made a very pleasing Prinoe Koko, and in the hands of Mr. P. Esposito, the Court Magioian and Astrologer Ski Hi was a great soooees. Mr. J. Capponi, as Pat Murphy, was quite in his element and kept the large audience in continued. merriment The minor characters were well played by Messrs. P. Perdikides, A. Rathte, V. Paaootto, A. Akaoui, P. Galatis, Z. Simaika, C. Demozantos, S. Stamos, H. Chriatodoulou, and S. Noto. Hie songs and choruses were exceedingly well rendered and brought forth rounds of applause. The staging was admirable, and the costumes gorgeous. Throughout the performance net a point was missed, whksb speaks volumes for the excellence of the college method, seeing that not a single English youth appeared in the piece. The second portion of the programme was devoted to a musical pieoe by Le Roy Villiers entitled Le Moulin du chat qui fume, which went with a swing that was highly creditable to all concerned, Messrs. G. Mansour, Z. Mooktar, A. Miohaoa, G, Saunier, 8. Noto, and V, Pasootto being equally successful in their respective rCles. Too much praise cannot be awarded Bro. Jerome for the capable in which the various selections were performed by his orchestra, the youthful members of which he has so carefully trained, the Pot Pourri from Il Trouvalors and les Hers de Oeur by Von Suppe being paicularly admired.

div.head: Questions Municipales
div.p: LA JETÉE-PROMBNADE DU POUT EST
Bains de Mer Populaires

La Commission Municipale vient de renvoyer aux Comités des Finances et des Travaux Publics la proposition de M. Joseph concernant rétablissement d'une jetée-promenade au Port- Est. On sait que ce M. Joseph avaitpréseuté depuis longtemps un projet à la Municipalité. Mais celle-ci avait constamment fait la sourde oreille et malgré les instances réitérées de l'entrepreneur, l'aflaire était bel et bien enterrée.

Soudain, le 10 janvier écoulé, la Délégation s'empare de la question, l'étudie, l'embellit de projets de bains, et la soumet ainsi modifiée à la Commission. Celle-ci vient de la renvoyer aux comités compétents. *

Cette résurrectiou par la Délégation d'une proposition qu elle avait dédaignée tout d'abord a eu le don de nous intriguer. Nous avons voulu voir la teneur de lotira de cet heureux M. Joseph. Or, quelle n'a pas .été notre surprise de constater qu'il ne parlait pas de bains, mais qu'en revauche il réclamait le monopole non pas du Port-Est seulement mais de toute la ville et banlieue depuis Has-el-Tin jusqu a llamleh. De plus les bénéfices de la Municipalité sont établis dans son projet sur une base absolument illusoire.

Ces bains que la Délégatiou met en avant et dont l'ofire de M. Joseph ne dit pas un mot seraient utiles sans doute, et môme nécessaires, mais ils sont irréalisables, il est matériellement impossible d'installer des bains dans le Port- Est tant a cause de la profondeur de l'eau que de la violence des vagues. s
La proposition si séduisante des bains de mer populaires doit donc être abandonnée. EÜe est destinéo à rester une pure chimère tant qu'on n'aura pas construit un port d'abri.
Ceci dit, la Commission et les comités municipaux peuvent maintenant prendre uue décision en toute counaissance de cause.

div.head: THE RAILWAY REPORT
NOTE ON SIGNALS & SIGNALLING.
div.p: The signal» throughout the Egyptian State Railways are in an unsatisfactory state, there is an entire absence of system, and the present difficulties have not been diminished by the -.sue oi complicated and .voluminous instruc* lions. The existing regulations with regatd to signals should bo simplified as much as possi- t»ie, aim every man concerned should be made to understand that a train must not passa stop signal under any circumstances when at the :.eager position. Special care is required to keep the wires adjusted, and in re arranging ;iic station signals it is recommended they be oade us simple a» possible, and that each •ration should be protected by borne or stop signal' which should be placed beyond the utlyiug pointai It distant signals are Ux be employed at aU on lines of minor importance, it should be distinctly understood that they .re mere n? pea tels of the home signal, it is 'oiisiderçd however that on the lines of minor mportaiice, it would be better to treat all .gnus as stop signals, and to arrange accordingly

It Was noticed at several stations that the frequent use of red flags on the part of the station staff hadrendered them of little real effect. A red flag should be regarded as an absolute stop signal by all concerned. At some stations of many as six men were alternately showing red and green flags: this can only cause confusion to the enguine drivers. With regard to the interlocking of the signals, which si now being carried out at Kantara and at some other places where signal boxes have already been erected, the levers were so arranged that the signal menwould have their backs to the trains when working the levers. This should be

*ion staff hud rendered them oi little real effect \ red flag should be regarded os an absolute top signal by all concerned. At some stations I . > many as six men were alternately show mg ted and gfeen flags: this can only cause confusion to the eugine drivers. W ith regard to the interlocking of the signals, which is now being carried out at Kantara -and at some other places where signal boxes Lave already been erected, the levers were so arranged that the signal men would have their backs to the trains

In one case (Kau- tura) where the interlocking was finished, there was nothing to prevent the signal man lowering the home signals for two trains approaching on the same liue from opposite ways. At a slight cost this can be corrected and the traius crossed to the left, it should be stated that the interlocking arrangements recently completed at Boulac Dacrour appeared satisfactory.
INTERLOCKING MAIN LINE STATIONS AND JUNCTIONS.

It is important that the work of interlocking the signals at all the junctions in Lower Egypt shotfki be completed as soon as possible, aud that such stations as Cairo, Alexandria, Tan- tah, Damauhour, Mausourah aud Zagazig should be properly laid out and signalled.
Were it uot that each engine is piloted through the important junctions and into the terminal stations, the working of the trains would not be safe.
The coustruction and maintenance of signals should be under the charge of the Chief Engineer, who should also consult the Truftic and Ijncomotive Departments in their nrrrangement aud working.
SWING BRIDGES.

The swing bridges on the main line between L'uiro and Alexandria, and Cairo and Port Said should be interlocked in such manner that the bridges cannot be opened while the signals protecting them are at danger. This work is urgent, it should be followed by the interlock- of all the other swiug bridges.

div.head: THE CAIRO "SALON."
div.p: Not Up To Standard.

The exhibition of pictures at the Cercle Artistique, Cairo, is uot quite up to the standurd of previous years, although some charuiiug exceptions relieve the eye from a general impression of mediocrity. Of the well-known artists we sadly feel the absence of Messrs. Talbot-Kelly, Varley, and Radii, though we welcome the advent ot Mr. Ashton, w hose water colours of Egyptian scenery are of a very high order. Among the well known Cairo artists may be specially mentioned the beautitul architectural subjects ot M. Meuuier. It is bard to say which is the best ot these charming effects of colour added to exquisite detail, but we iucline to favor "Temple of Abou Bimbel'' (No. 117:) the figures in this stand up witb daring boldness above the sand. "Vallée des Rois" [Thebes] (No. 179,) by the same artist, is a gem of soft colour with a blue sky of wonderful depth. There are many excellent Bear veil is, delicate and finished, "Le Retour des Pèlerins," (No. 124J and "Le depart da Tapis" (No. Iu7j deserving special attention. In the former the idea of a vast crowd is wonderfully shown and there is a very pleasing feeling ot mistiness iu the background. The crowd is quite as well portrayed in the beautiful street scene of No. 107 : there is plenty of detail, but depth aud breadth at the same time. Two of Rossi's stand out from the rest—llanem (No. 62,) a clever portrait of a girl full of bright colour,and Fantasia (No. 80.) There are also several good pictures of Bouello Bcarvelli, and two good landscapes of Philippo* teaux. All Mr. Ashton's water colours are graceful and finished and full ot excellent col-, our—notably Rhoda Island (No. 126)—which includes a view of the Citade with the Nile in the foreground : the evening effect is particularly good. "La Vallée du Nil" (No.147 is equally deserving of praise : the view is from the Mokattas, and the effect of the large rock in the foreground is particularly good The colors are beautiful clear.

There is only one first rate portrait, and that is No. 19, "JUoghos Pasha," by^artugnes,which is uot only a speaking likeness, but thoroughly artistic in design, the bleudiug of the colours of background and face is particularly good. Second to this is No. 13 "Bedouin" by M. G. Gasté, a pleasing picture with plenty of light colour.

Among others worthy of mention are No. 86 Sur la porte" by Rossi—a picture of a native girl standing under an .elaborately carved door : the etFect of light on her forehead is good. Another very good colour effect is iu No. 68 "Khan el Khalil" by Bcarvelli : the red cloth catching the light outside a dark arch very successfully. There are many more Meuniers—a particularly good one being Village d'El Meclietti" No. 142—shewing bright colouring on the shore of the Assouan dam. M. Das tag nes 'ha* another good portrait No. 37 "Fathma"-V native girl with a particularly good background, which adds greatly to the lightness of the picture. There are two clever •ketches of M. Beroud with plenty of light colour, "Une rue au Caire" No. 25 aud No. 23 "Porte au Mou ski, which is clearly the Bah el Mitwali. Both these sketches are rough in the extreme, but give exceileut ell ecu from a distance, particularly No. 23. Mr. Royle has two watercolours, oue of which No. 180, 'Temple de Mebmel Abou" has much to recommend iu it. Of the two large oils of M. Philip* poteaux, we preier No. 16, "Sur les plateaux de Brach" : the whole laudscape is somewhat too bright. A striking sketch, hung rather high by the way, is "Retour de la promenade' No. 64 by Scarvelli, which shews very cleverly the wonderful effect, which so many people admire but so few have dared to copy, the sunset glow as seen looking westward along the bridge from Kasr-el-Nil. Mr. J. P. Forcellajias a charming pastelle iu No.2. "Lueurs d'Orient' —native women carrying water pots : the effect ot motion is extremely good : he iB also very successful iu No. 3 "Heures.chaudes" —an oil sketch of a door with figures sitting. Of thoso pictures which occupy much space, we cannot conclude without mentioning No. 167 "Portrait de M. G." by Guetin. It is a pleasing fact to notice that several English residents are beginning to take an interest in.this annual exhibition, and to find sketchs of Mr. G. L. Aldereon, the Rev. F. Anderson, Mr. Foxcroft and others, many of which show considerable merit and promise.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The statement that it is proposed to with; draw the British troops from Egypt» altogether is received with some incredulity. Despite the desire of the Army Council to assist Mr. Arnold-Forster in his work of retrenchment and reform, it would be going much too far to entirely denude Egypt of the troops which occupy such a very favorable strategical situation. The present state of politics in Europe may not last for ever.

On the 16th prox. Major-General J. R. Blade, C.B , Royal Artillerj, commanding the troops in Egypt, will retire under the age rules. The service will lose a good soldier by his retirement, and certainly no more popular oue ever commanded at Cairo.

Captain W. E G. Connolly, Royal Marine Light Infantry.&ttached to the Egyptian Army, has been promoted major on tho establishment. Major Connolly joined the R.M.L.I. in September, 1886, and spent the past three and a-half years with the Khedive's troops.
Colonel Walter G.Crole-Wyndham, C.B.,who charged with the 21st LaDcers at Omdurman, has been appointed to the command of the sixth ilivisiou at Plymouth.

Captain R. C. Maclachl&n, adjutant of the 3rd Battalion, Rifle Brigade, at Aden—now on home leave—will vacate that appointment on the 6th prox. and will be succeeded by Captain George Pally, who lately passed through the Stafl' College. Captain Pally has served with the Rifle Brigade for nearly thirteen years, and **08 with the 2nd Battalion in Kitchener's Khartoum expedition, including the battle of that name (medal and Khedive's medal with clasp).
Tho old ironclad "Hecla," which was at the bombardment of Alexandria, is about to be sent out to Houg-Kong to act as the depot ship to the "destroyer" flotillas on the China Station.
The first-class battleship "Vengeance" will bo commissioned at Malta on the 28th inst for two years' service on tho Mediterranean Station, where she proceeds from the China
Station.

div.head: FUNERALS IN CAIRO.
div.p: A correspondent writes calling attention to the manner in which funerals are conducted in Cairo, He says: I have to emphasise and deplore what I can only call an entire absence of decency in the lesser details; and those details are catually of greater import than all else. I refer to the attendants to whom is entrusted the handling - I must use the word- of those buried in our cemetery. I d not wish to enlarge on their methods or on that apathy, the result of long habit and natural lack of sympathy, which of all things produces the most painful and jarring effect. Of all that enters into our life, the one greatest fact diminating us should be - it is in Egypy - the last farewell to those who have been taken away from us, so often suddenly. Why should our thoughts, at a moment when regret and reflection are at a climax, be disturbed even ourtaged by causes of which the remedy is in our own hands: why should our friends be lowered into their resting place by those who (whatever may be their personality and merit) must, racially, be out of sympathy and so without feeling for what concerns us so intimately: Do we take any part in the funeral services of those who belong to this country, or indeed (expect that of respect born of friendship or sympth) of those of another church? it would be a gross offence. Why then cannot we, a community of so many English, find some amongst us who will, from feeling rather than paid duty, mitigate and harmonise the trouble of the last offices to those we lose Surely the friends of him or her we follow would be ready and glad to offer themselves to show in the painful and unavoidable details that reverence and respect they feel, so that all who have greatest cause to mourn may know that everyone present is with the, honoring their sorrow, and in so far as in each lies, sparing all that may needlessly offend or enhance it. Let us then have reason to feel that if one or other of ourselves die, away from our country, they may be not only followed to their grave, but also laid therin by other who are living - as they have died - and for, though not of, Egypt.

div.head: LENT.
BY BARONESS DE MALORTIE
div.p: Before the Father's Face we kneel to pray ;
Yet only though the best beloved Son
Can we approach that glorious array
Of worlds unknown, all blended into One.
O Light Eternal! Guide our erring ways :
They fall aong the throns, the cares, the sin.
Leth cleansed hearts feel loved again, and praise,
In offering this Sacrifice to Him
O mystic Life, that flows within the Cup,
O Strength of God, that hides within the Bread,
We languish ! who by these are lifeted up ;
We hunger ! whom the Great Unseen has fed.
Increased our faith. O could we live by Thee,
Patience Divine ! but waiting for our loves,
Making it part of Thy dread Majesty.
ROund which the brightest Angels only move.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie

div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour jardins en pitch pine ou Suède.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 20.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau du Nettoiement où U peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi,les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 21 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention "Soumission pour Bancs et Chaises."
Le cautionnement on le reçu d'une banque, d'après les oonditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis à la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 21 Mars à midi.

div.head: THE DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY LIMITED
div.p: Notice to Shareholders.

In accordance with the terms of the Addi tioual Article of the 4th June 1904 to the Agreement of the 18th November 1902, enter ed into between the Comptrollers of the Daira Sanieb, acting under the authority of their respective Governments, And the Daira Sanieb Company Limited, the Uneaten now propose to constitute a Company under Egyptian Law which is to take over the assets and liabilities of this Company. A draft Agreement for this purpose will be submitted for consideration at the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Shareholders to be held on the 27th inst
On the same day, separate meetings of the holders of Ordinary and of Deferred Shares will be held in aooordanoe with Artiole 25 of the Articles of Association.
S. De Bilinski,
Secretary. Sharia Kasr-el-Nil,
Cairo, 4th March 1905.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited, will be held at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, on Monday the 27th day of March 1905 at 3 o'clock in the afternoon for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolution.
RESOLUTION.

That the Board be authorised to enter into an Agreement with a Company about to be formed under Egyptian Law with the title of "La Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh" or some similar title, or with a Trustee for such Company, in the terms of draft which will be submitted to the Meeting, subject to such modifications as the Board may think fit, for the sale to such oompany of the whole of the undertaking, business and assets of the Company, subject to its liabilities, and that this Meeting hereby sanctions the scheme of distribution of the proceeds of sale therein provided for.
Dated this fourth day of March 1905.
By Order of the Board.
S. de Billns&i,
Secretary.
Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
